    • convolve

      public static double[] convolve(double[] a, double[] b, int length)
      Convolution of two arrays through 0-padding and Convolution Theorem

      f * g = IFFT(FFT(f) x FFT(g)) such that FFT(f) and FFT(g) are of length f.length + g.length - 1

      Parameters:
      a - first array of real numbers to be convolved
      b - second array of real numbers to be convolved
      length - the length of the resulting array, 0 < length <= a.length + b.length - 1
      Returns:
      the resulting array of real numbers after convolution truncated to length

    • convolve

      public static double[] convolve(double[] a, double[] b)
      Convolution of two arrays through 0-padding and Convolution Theorem

      f * g = IFFT(FFT(f) x FFT(g)) such that FFT(f) and FFT(g) are of length f.length + g.length - 1

      Parameters:
      a - first array of real numbers to be convolved
      b - second array of real numbers to be convolved
      Returns:
      the resulting array of real numbers after convolution with length a.length + b.length - 1

    • convolve

      public static Complex[] convolve(Complex[] a, Complex[] b, int length)
      Convolution of two arrays through 0-padding and Convolution Theorem

      f * g = IFFT(FFT(f) x FFT(g)) such that FFT(f) and FFT(g) are of length f.length + g.length - 1

      Parameters:
      a - first array of complex numbers to be convolved
      b - second array of complex numbers to be convolved
      length - the length of the resulting array, 0 < length <= a.length + b.length - 1
      Returns:
      the resulting array of Complex numbers after convolution truncated to length

    • convolve

      public static Complex[] convolve(Complex[] a, Complex[] b)
      Convolution of two arrays through 0-padding and Convolution Theorem

      f * g = IFFT(FFT(f) x FFT(g)) such that FFT(f) and FFT(g) are of length f.length + g.length - 1

      Parameters:
      a - first array of complex numbers to be convolved
      b - second array of complex numbers to be convolved
      Returns:
      the resulting array of Complex numbers after convolution with length a.length + b.length - 1

    • cyclicConvolve

      public static double[] cyclicConvolve(double[] a, double[] b)
      Cyclic convolution of two arrays through Circular Convolution Theorem

      f * g = IFFT(FFT(f) x FFT(g)) such that FFT(f) and FFT(g) are of length max(f.length, g.length)

      Parameters:
      a - first array of real numbers to be convolved
      b - second array of real numbers to be convolved
      Returns:
      the resulting array of real numbers after cyclic convolution

    • cyclicConvolve

      public static Complex[] cyclicConvolve(Complex[] a, Complex[] b)
      Cyclic convolution of two arrays through Circular Convolution Theorem

      f * g = IFFT(FFT(f) x FFT(g)) such that FFT(f) and FFT(g) are of length max(f.length, g.length)

      Parameters:
      a - first array of complex numbers to be convolved
      b - second array of complex numbers to be convolved
      Returns:
      the resulting array of Complex numbers after cyclic convolution

    • besseli

      public static double besseli(int k, int x)
      Modified Bessel function of the first kind of a generalized order

      Utilizes Miller's recurrence algorithm

      https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miller%27s_recurrence_algorithm

      based on Numeric Recipes

      Parameters:
      k - the order of the Bessel function
      x - the argument of the Bessel function
      Returns:
      the value of the Bessel function at the given order and argument
